docs.lead_paragraph: The abortion issue has put members of Congress who support abortion rights in a quandary over the health care legislation.

headline.main: In Congress, a Predicament for Abortion Supporters

docs.abstract: Members of Congress who support abortion rights face a quandary over whether to compromise on the issue and vote for health care legislation that would otherwise improve health care for women.
docs.snippet: Members of Congress who support abortion rights face a quandary over whether to compromise on the issue and vote for health care legislation that would otherwise improve health care for women.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, Room for Debate discussed the Congressional health care legislation and whether it does enough to address the inflation in medical bills.

headline.main: More Ways to Drive Down Medical Bills

docs.abstract: Some culprits: doctors and nurses make too much, and drug companies set high prescription prices.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama and leading Democratic lawmakers have repeatedly said that illegal immigrants would not be eligible for subsidies to buy health insurance on the proposed national exchanges. But what if they wanted to buy the insurance with their own money? Readers have been debating the question on The Times's online forum Health Care Conversations. Here is a sampling of comments: If insurance were affordable and some undocumented immigrants bought insurance, there would be that many fewer people using the E.R. for non-emergency health care and that much less burden on the taxpayer. M

docs.lead_paragraph: MBIA, the financial insurance company, used to hold itself out as a paragon of hard work and number crunching.

headline.main: Norris: A Lack of Rigor Costs MBIA

docs.abstract: MBIA's once pristine AAA-rating has now turned into junk and no one wants to buy insurance from the company, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column.
